explanationSteps.text: Type safety catches errors at compile time instead of runtime. When TypeScript knows a variable's type, it can prevent operations that would fail — like calling .length on undefined.
explanationSteps.title: Compile-Time Safety

explanationSteps.text: TypeScript uses structural typing — it cares about shape, not names. Two types are compatible if they have the same structure, even if defined separately.
explanationSteps.title: Structural Typing

explanationSteps.text: Type narrowing lets TypeScript understand more specific types after checks. Inside an if-block that checks for null, TypeScript knows the value isn't null.
explanationSteps.title: Type Narrowing

explanationSteps.text: Generic types let you write reusable code that works with multiple types while preserving type information. Array<T> knows what's inside, unlike just 'Array'.
explanationSteps.title: Generics

explanationSteps.text: The 'any' type disables type checking entirely. It's an escape hatch but defeats the purpose of TypeScript. Use 'unknown' when the type truly isn't known.
explanationSteps.title: Any vs Unknown

explanationSteps.text: Type guards are functions that narrow types. They return a type predicate that tells TypeScript what the type is after the check passes.
explanationSteps.title: Type Guards

explanationSteps.text: Game theory studies strategic interactions where your outcome depends on others' choices too. It's not about games — it's about any situation where what you should do depends on what others do.
explanationSteps.title: Strategic Interdependence

explanationSteps.text: A Nash equilibrium is a stable state where no player can improve by changing only their own strategy. Everyone is doing their best given what everyone else is doing.
explanationSteps.title: Nash Equilibrium

explanationSteps.text: A dominant strategy is best regardless of what others do. If you have one, use it. But most real situations don't have dominant strategies — you must anticipate others.
explanationSteps.title: Dominant Strategies

explanationSteps.text: The prisoner's dilemma shows how individual rationality can lead to collective irrationality. Both players choosing their dominant strategy leaves both worse off.
explanationSteps.title: The Prisoner's Dilemma

explanationSteps.text: Repeated games change the calculus. When you'll interact again, cooperation becomes rational because future punishment makes defection costly.
explanationSteps.title: Repeated Interactions

explanationSteps.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is a molecular scissors that cuts DNA at specific locations. The Cas9 protein does the cutting; a guide RNA tells it exactly where to cut.
explanationSteps.title: The Molecular Scissors

explanationSteps.text: Guide RNA is a short sequence that matches the target DNA. It base-pairs with the DNA sequence you want to edit, bringing Cas9 to the exact spot.
explanationSteps.title: Guide RNA Targeting

explanationSteps.text: After CRISPR cuts, the cell's repair machinery fixes the break. Non-homologous end joining often introduces errors (knockouts). Homology-directed repair can insert new sequences (knock-ins).
explanationSteps.title: Cellular Repair Pathways

explanationSteps.text: Off-target effects occur when CRISPR cuts unintended locations. Guide RNA design and delivery methods affect specificity. This is a major safety concern for therapeutic applications.
explanationSteps.title: Off-Target Effects

explanationSteps.text: Delivery is a key challenge. Getting CRISPR components into the right cells in a living organism is harder than in a lab dish. Viral vectors and lipid nanoparticles are common approaches.
explanationSteps.title: Delivery Challenges

explanationSteps.text: The CAP theorem states you can only have two of three: Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance. Since network partitions happen, you're really choosing between C and A.
explanationSteps.title: CAP Theorem

explanationSteps.text: Strong consistency means all nodes see the same data at the same time. Every read returns the most recent write. This requires coordination that can slow things down.
explanationSteps.title: Strong Consistency

explanationSteps.text: Eventual consistency means replicas will converge given enough time without new writes. Reads might return stale data temporarily, but the system stays available.
explanationSteps.title: Eventual Consistency

explanationSteps.text: Network partitions occur when nodes can't communicate. The system must decide: reject requests (maintain consistency) or accept requests that might conflict (maintain availability).
explanationSteps.title: Partition Handling

explanationSteps.text: Quorum-based systems use voting. A write succeeds if enough replicas acknowledge it. Read quorum + write quorum > total nodes ensures reading at least one up-to-date copy.
explanationSteps.title: Quorum Systems

explanationSteps.text: Conflict resolution strategies handle divergent writes: last-write-wins, vector clocks, or application-specific merge logic. The right choice depends on your data semantics.
explanationSteps.title: Conflict Resolution

userInput.lessonDescription: Navigating consistency and availability trade-offs in distributed systems

explanationSteps.text: Loss aversion means losses hurt more than equivalent gains feel good — roughly twice as much. People will take irrational risks to avoid losses they wouldn't take to achieve gains.
explanationSteps.title: Loss Aversion

explanationSteps.text: Framing effects show that how you present options matters as much as what the options are. '90% survival rate' and '10% mortality rate' are logically identical but feel different.
explanationSteps.title: Framing Effects

explanationSteps.text: Default effects are powerful because people tend to stick with pre-selected options. Changing the default can dramatically change outcomes without restricting choice.
explanationSteps.title: Default Effects

explanationSteps.text: Present bias makes us overvalue immediate rewards over future ones. We know we should save for retirement, but the money feels more valuable now. Commitment devices help.

explanationSteps.text: The null hypothesis (H0) is the default assumption of no effect. We try to reject it. The p-value measures how surprising the data would be IF the null were true.
explanationSteps.title: Null Hypothesis

explanationSteps.text: A p-value is NOT the probability the null is true. It's the probability of seeing data this extreme (or more) if the null IS true. A common and dangerous misinterpretation.
explanationSteps.title: P-Value Meaning

explanationSteps.text: Type I error (false positive) is rejecting a true null. Type II error (false negative) is failing to reject a false null. You can't minimize both — there's a trade-off.
explanationSteps.title: Error Types

explanationSteps.text: Statistical power is the probability of detecting a real effect. It depends on sample size, effect size, and significance level. Low-powered studies miss real effects.
explanationSteps.title: Statistical Power

explanationSteps.text: Statistical significance doesn't mean practical significance. A huge sample can detect tiny effects that don't matter in practice. Always consider effect size.
explanationSteps.title: Practical Significance

explanationSteps.text: Multiple comparisons inflate Type I errors. Testing 20 hypotheses at alpha=0.05 expects one false positive. Corrections like Bonferroni or FDR control this.
explanationSteps.title: Multiple Comparisons

explanationSteps.text: Qubits can exist in superposition — a weighted combination of 0 and 1 states. This isn't 'both at once' — it's a probability amplitude that interferes before measurement.
explanationSteps.title: Superposition

explanationSteps.text: Entanglement links qubits so measuring one instantly determines the other, regardless of distance. This correlation is a resource for quantum algorithms.
explanationSteps.title: Entanglement

explanationSteps.text: Quantum parallelism lets algorithms evaluate functions on all inputs simultaneously. But you can only read one result — the art is using interference to amplify the right answer.
explanationSteps.title: Quantum Parallelism

explanationSteps.text: Decoherence destroys quantum information when qubits interact with their environment. Real qubits are noisy and maintain coherence only briefly.
explanationSteps.title: Decoherence

explanationSteps.text: Quantum error correction encodes logical qubits in many physical qubits. The overhead is huge — thousands of physical qubits per logical qubit for fault tolerance.
explanationSteps.title: Error Correction

explanationSteps.text: Quantum advantage requires the right problem type. Factoring, simulation, and certain optimization problems benefit. Most classical algorithms won't be replaced.
explanationSteps.title: Where Quantum Helps

steps.conclusion: The twist in Scene 6 contains a mathematical inaccuracy regarding the application of calculus to the tank problem. The colleague states that switching to a cheaper steel (requiring greater thickness) turned the previous 'minimum' point into a 'maximum'. In standard optimization, changing material constants (density, price, constant thickness) only scales the function by a positive constant, which does not affect the location or nature (concavity) of the critical point. Even if thickness depended on radius (e.g., hoop stress), it is highly unlikely to invert the function from convex to concave at the same point without a more complex explanation. While the correct answer ('The objective function changed') is conceptually right, the scenario's specific claim ('it is now a maximum') is mathematically misleading for a standard cylinder problem.
